Today, we have professors
Bob Sutton and Huggy Rao, and as we move to this
session over the next hour,

if you're enjoying
the insights and you'd like to learn more, you can check out both
Bob and Huggy's courses
within the certificate they have been linked directly in your dashboard so you can play around with that and find it.

We're going to jump
right in today. If you would like to learn
more about Huggy and

Bob's backgrounds or
anything about Taliesha, you'll find all those resources
linked in your dashboard.

I'm not going to go for
the lengthy introduction. Without further
ado, Bob and Huggy, it's always a pleasure.
Take us away. Thank you so very much, Robin.

Bob and I are of course, delighted to be here with our audience today and
we're all the more

gratified to be here
because we have our thousand graduate,
Taliesha Garrett.

One of the things Bob
and I thought was, we might actually begin

by having a short
conversation with Taliesha and then opening it up

for then Ask Me Any
Question format. Taliesha, thank you for being so

generous and sharing
your time with us. Congratulations on being
our thousand graduate.

What I wanted to ask you was, how would you describe getting
to the arc of your career,

so to speak, getting
to this stage? [OVERLAPPING] Are
there milestones, are there stages that
stand out for you?

[NOISE] Thank you Huggy and thank
you all for having me here. There are certainly milestones
that I would say have

been anchors or pillars
to get where I am today. When I think about milestones,

I think about those moments that are really transformational, that really helped me
grow and go deeper.

I can't help but think of a couple that standard
out the most. One is, this was the
moment that I learned

that my success will never climb higher
than my character.

I learned this moment early
in my career, thank God.

I was fresh out of undergrad, I had gotten a
really cool position on a pretty cool company.

I was a junior financial analysts and I was living the dream. I thought I had it
made, I had arrived.

There was a team of like
seven or eight of us and we were all young, ambitious, we were single so we
can work 18 hour days,
it was just we were all in, and it was fantastic. I started getting acknowledge

for the value that I brought to table and skills and
abilities that I had, and I was getting promoted and
recognized pretty quickly.

Then there came a
moment after a couple of years where I
just hit a plateau. I was still delivering,

I was still performing, but I wasn't getting
promoted anymore, and I started to get
really bitter about it.

[NOISE] I started to
feel very entitled, and very just arrogant really,

thinking that here I am, I'm giving it all, why
don't they see me?
Out of pure bitterness, I left the team I was on and took

a lateral move because I thought a new team is going
to make all the difference. I just need to be in

a different place and
they'll see my value [NOISE] and I'll keep getting
promoted and my career. will just skyrocket in.

About three to four months
after I left the team, they promoted someone who I

on-boarded and trained
to lead that department, and I was devastated.

I was convinced that this
person stole my job, I was convinced that
it was personal,

I was convinced that
they were out to get me, and that this wasn't fair.

After a lot of reflection and talking
to mentors and coaches,

I learned that I wasn't
getting promoted because my attitude
was really poor,

and I had really developed, like I said earlier,
an arrogance of

entitlement because I thought that my skills were all I needed, and I put everything I had
into developing my skills.

There was the saying that you left dead bodies and
then they had the path,

[LAUGHTER] and I
didn't realize that. I was so focused on getting

the job done right that
it went to my head and I didn't realize how
much damage I was creating.

That was the moment where
I realized, wow, okay, my skill will only get me so far,
but my character and how I interact with other people is what will [NOISE] sustain me.

I took about two or
three years and really started doing a
lot of inner work,

thinking about who
do I want to be. Almost like an identity
crisis of who am I.

I had spent so much time being who I thought I was
supposed to be and

focusing on the skills I
thought I was supposed to have, and focusing on the next job,

the next title, the
next upward movement. Once I realized that it was
so much deeper than that,

I started becoming a lot less impressed with titles,
and positions,

and salaries, and I was
more impressed with the inner person of tell me

what's behind the title
and the position, and really helped me
understand you as a person.

Once that lens shifted from me, and I don't think it
was a coincidence,

but that's when my career
really started to take off, of when the lens of focusing

on building a solid
foundation took place. That was probably one of the
biggest lessons I've learned

as far as in my
professional life, was that my skill set
will only get me so far.

Thank you for that beautiful
account, Taliesha.

It's an account that
I would say with searing honesty and
self-reflection. Thank you.

Here's the way I heard you, and I wanted to run it by you. The way I heard it was
the big aha for you was,

"Hey, I need to move
from skill to self." Yes.

>> The real thing in
life is not choosing one job or another
or being promoted to

one job or another
but really what matters is which version of
yourself are you choosing.

Is that a reasonable way
to say what you said? >> Absolutely, and I
think for me at the time,
I was so confused about myself. [NOISE] I had so much.

Visually you can see
I'm a black woman. I'm biracial, my
grandmother is Caucasian,

my mother is mixed, and so I grew up in this
space of not really

being clear on which version
of myself was acceptable. [NOISE] Not really being
clear on who I was

and what was important and always doing the sense
of just being other. [NOISE].

There was a box that I just, for the like of me,
could not fit into. When I entered the
corporate space,

in my mind, that was my opportunity to
fit inside the box. [NOISE] That was my opportunity
to if anything else,

I'm going to be the
best performer here. I'm going to outshine
anyone I can. I'm going to be in this box
of what corporate success is

defined or at least what I thought it was their
[NOISE] defined as.
That didn't work and so through that phase of self-reflection,

I realized fitting in the
box may not be the goal. >> Right.

>> Maybe the goal is
not to fit in the box. What if this otherness that I had

felt all of this time is
really my superpower? What if I can embrace that,

and rather than reject the pieces of myself
that I felt were other,

what if I can start to embrace
that and leverage that and learn more and gain

the confidence in
being able to show up? [NOISE] Being other is okay. That really settled for me
when I had my daughter because

[NOISE] we live in a predominantly Caucasian
area and she's brown skinned.

When she started asking
questions about her otherness, it really [NOISE]
started to highlight in

me the areas of my otherness that was
important [NOISE] to race.

Again, how do we take this? What feels like
something we should

change and then
[NOISE] embrace it as something we can
really accentuate. >> That's [NOISE] really
beautifully put, Taliesha.

The way I heard it
was in phase 1, your emphasis was conformity
and assimilation in work matters. Then phase 2 it's
actually me getting in

touch with my best
self or who I am. I'm curious as I listen
to you [NOISE] and I

imagine many in the audience are obviously listening
very intently,

might you actually share
with us this tension between being an exception
and being exceptional?

>> Yeah. >> Is one an exception in
the eyes of other people? Do we have to be exceptional
in the sense of getting

in touch with our
exceptional self or is it the other way around? >> I think we become exceptional

by getting in touch
with our best self. But I think sometimes we
only get the drive to

become exceptional when we realize we're not
really the exception,

[LAUGHTER] if that makes sense. >> That's well put. >> I think that for a long
time I was the exception.

My mom had me at 16 years old. All the odds about what
success looked like and

what kind of environment
you needed to breed success were against me. I grew up in a relatively
poor community.

There were no silver
spoons in sight.

Once I started, I had this driver Leon to know that I
wanted to go to college.
I knew I wanted to go to college, but no one else had done it. My uncle graduated college.

He was the first to do it. There was just a lot of exception just in my upward
mean. You beat the odds.

That exception is what
bred in me this idea of; I thought that the exception

was I had hit the
lottery or something. [NOISE] It was this
locker in the drawer

where [NOISE] it's just me. It's just me [NOISE]
and this is just how I am and lucky me.

It wasn't until I started to go through the cycles
of learning like,

"Oh man, I really need to
focus on my inner self. Some of these outer things
are not going to sustain me",

and I started embracing all
the things that made me the exception and looking at

those from a reflective
please and saying, "You know what, there are
some really good skills and abilities that I do
have, and that's okay.

Yes, there are a lot
of areas where I may be the exception for some, but there are some
exceptional qualities

that I have and that I can embrace and that [NOISE] I
can bring to the table." Although yes, there are a lot of

things in my upbringing that
were stacked against me, there was also a lot of work
and effort that I put in

to ensure that I
would be exceptional. >> Right. >> But I found that,

as I said a little bit ago, some of that feeling of an
exception and that otherness,

I've really been
able to embrace that and turn it into somewhat
of a superpower. Yes, I am different.

You may think I'm other compared to your lens
and that's okay.

In that, there are still some amazing qualities
that I naturally

have and that I've
developed and continue to grow in that I'm going to
bring to the table as well.

>> Taliesha coming back to
what you were just saying, one question I had was,

what did you think of the
S-I-N-D learning opportunity?

Was that like a gem for you to help choose a different

>> Yeah, it was certainly
a gem, I would say. As I got into this journey,

I don't know if I've
become cynical about it, but I'm less impressed
with credentials.

Certainly, I'm rarely a fan unless it's something
compliance-related,

I'm rarely a fan of getting a certification for the sake of saying I have a certification, it just doesn't make
sense to me conceptually,

and it's a waste
of time, frankly. This in the case
was such a gem in that one of the strengths that

I realized I had was this
going against the grain, challenging the
process, I'll say.

Thinking outside the box and all those terms that we
now call innovation.

But I didn't have a good framework to
really [NOISE] bring that

into a corporate space because often [NOISE] times innovation is looked at as
entrepreneurial ship.

I think the biggest lesson I've learned and the reason why this course was a gem
for me is it really

taught me about intrapreneurship. How do I take those entrepreneurial
mindsets and

apply them into the
infrastructure of a company? How do I embrace that

going against the grain and embrace the challenging process, and embrace the asking lots
of questions and developing

an innate sense of curiosity to inspire innovation
in the workplace?

For me, I don't have a desire
to be an entrepreneur. I used to connect

entrepreneurial innovation as one and that they go hand
in hand and they do,
but I learned from this program, I can also bring that innovative mindset right where I'm at,

into the work that I do. It's been great. My directors have certainly noticed a
difference and provided

lots of feedback and
embraced the ideas of let's looking at this like
it's our own enterprise.

What would we do differently? [OVERLAPPING] How do
we lead differently?

>> Music to my ears and
Bob's ears as well.

As you think about innovators
or as you refer to them, intrapreneurs within
an enterprise,

if you were to think
of a simple equation intrapreneurship equals

two variables; curiosity
and generosity.

I'm wondering what
do you think is the relationship between
curiosity and generosity?

Is it additive, is
it multiplicative? For an innovator do
you need to have

curiosity squared multiplied by generosity or curiosity
multiplied by generosity squared?

You can imagine the
variations therein. What's your take
on? What matters?

>> Yeah. I think
curiosity and generosity are directly correlated and I

think they are
exponentially correlated. I think that curiosity

if I had to put this
in an equation, this is my language now. I think that curiosity to

the nth degree equals the
absolute value of generosity.

[NOISE] I think that the
more curious we are,
the more we are willing to give and be generous in giving.

That could be giving
in time or money, but also giving in thought, giving in energy,
giving in support.

I think that whatever
the topic is, the more curious
we are about that,

it exponentially increases
the totality of what we're willing to give into
addressing that curiosity.

>> That's beautifully put to me. That curiosity itself is
an act of active duty.

The act of asking the question itself
is an act of giving. >> Right. >> I've often thought
questions are gifts.
Asking about questions, might ask you a mischievous question? >> Sure.

>> What's the toughest
question you've asked at work? Off your boss of your
team, of anybody?

Toughest question you asked
anybody, or even of yourself. >> The type for
this question I've

asked was I had a really
contentious manager.

She was not much
short of a bully. She was just really
authoritative and hierarchical,
and it was her way or no way even if it didn't make sense. She had this rule,

and at the time I was
a relatively new mom, not her issue at all. The company was going

through trying to be
more accommodating to working virtually
and being more flexible with start
and stop times.

She was adamant that
every day we had to be there at 7:00 AM regardless.
No if, ands or buts.

We were there at seven sharp, and that was just the
rule because she said so.

Well, I had a childcare
arrangement where there was
a day where my nanny or my sitter was not able to get my daughter to school and

so I had to take her to school. I'm like, "This is
non-negotiable. I'm going to be late, take my daughter to school,
it is what it is."

We get there and she had
this whole conversation with me about why I needed
to be there at 7:00 AM,

and why this was
important for the team. I looked at her and I said,

"Demonstrate to me
how me being here at seven adds any more value
to you or the team."

She had no answer, and she was frustrated that
I questioned her authority.

We continued and I shared, I'm not one for rules
for the sake of power.

If that's not going to
work for you I'm happy to engage a jar and I'll be
glad to leave the team.

That was probably the most provocative or
provoking question

I've asked. >> It's a very powerful

voice of employees but

At this point listening

Really, my God,

what I mean use that to you. I'm wondering in your

products or business

>> This is one that I
observed, I'll say.

I wasn't directly a
part of but observed. At a company I was working

at we had implemented these communication
boards, if you will.

The idea was that you would
have a communication board at every part of the manufacturing
journey for that plant,

and they would have things like quality and safety and
people and whatnot.

Every morning at a certain time, you would walk the
leadership team, which I was a part
of at the time, would walk the boards and really

try to get status on the currency to production
and manufacturing.

When they went to implement this, the ground rules were pretty
simple in that it needed to

be started small and
organically grown, and it needed to be
led by the employees.

Pretty straightforward. You can imagine what the
leadership team did.

They do the opposite. They put boards everywhere
and they drove it.

The employees were
adamant and saying, "This is not the right time. This is more invasive to

our space than adding
any value for us. You're actually taking
away from productivity.

This is not a good fit
for us right now." The leadership team being as hierarchical as
they were they said,

"No, we got a mandate,
we got to go do it." Well, they didn't get a mandate. They got a set of
framework to implement,

but they read that as a mandate. Every several weeks we had
a VP of our manufacturing,
the entire division come and they'd walk the board with us. It was pretty systematic.

They came at the same time every few weeks to
make it, predict it. One of the weeks that they came,

the employees, because they
weren't getting heard, had gone on every board and

erased the row that said people, sending the message that
the people don't matter.

This isn't about the
people, this is about you. Simultaneously, at the
start of the meeting,

they started blasting over
the intercom circus music.

If you could see everyone's face when that
happened, it was priceless,

and that was certainly the biggest cluster
[LAUGHTER] I've observed,

because our director
had no clue what to do.

He was so caught off guard, he had no idea what
was happening. We all looked to and said,

"Well they've been
telling you this. They've been telling you
this isn't going to work." That was their way to
get the message across,

was to play circus music across
the VP walk that morning.

thank you so much. The most important thing about

leaders to my mind,
are recruiters. You can't do anything on
your own if you're a leader.

How are you going to
do anything on your own unless you recruit people? The most important thing to

understand is that as a leader, your fundamental task
is to be a recruiter.

You got to get people
to do things for you. What's going to
help you the most?

Being a hippopotamus
who constantly opens his or her mouth and doesn't
listen to other people,

that's not going to help you. Instead, being an elephant
helps you, being patient,

using all of your senses to listen and understand
your environment keenly,

that's actually
what's going to help. That to me is really the
essence of leadership.

Put simply, leaders are people
with a huge help muscle.

It goes back to the generosity
issue that Taliesha and I were just chatting about in
just a little while ago.

>> Excellent. That was Anna. I asked one of my colleagues.
Anna asked that question. Anna, thanks so much.

>> Thank you so much, Anna,
for asking that question. Hopefully, that was
of help to you. >> Absolutely. "Huggy, is

there any specific pattern
or format to present new ideas to managers if you're

an entry level individual
[NOISE] any tactics?"

>> Great question. [NOISE] Who
asked this question again?

>> I will know in a
minute. [LAUGHTER] >> I always want to recognize

the person who
asked the question. Maybe we'll track them. Whosoever asked the
question, thank you again.

Let me share with you
two bodies of research. One body of research shows
that if you present a superior, or for that matter, anybody, that a fully finished idea,
you're implicitly asking them to judge you and not help you.

Finished idea leads to
judgment, not help. What kind of idea leads to help?

A roughly finished
prototype of an idea is a better idea to elicit help

from the leader and the audience. Therefore, hand rough
ideas so that others

can add themselves into the idea and actually
develop it further.

That's one body of research. The other body of research
is when you present an idea,

your job is not to persuade
people but to presuade them. That means you don't want
to sell the idea to them.

Instead, you want them to be ready in order to
listen to the idea. So always think about
presuasion, not persuasion.

In this case, how would
you presuade somebody? You might presuade
somebody by saying, "Hey,

this idea came up because
just not my effort, but it was part of
a team effort."

That way, when you do that, you're immediately presuading
the audience, for example.

>> Excellent. Thank you, Huggy. That was, I might be
pronouncing this wrong,
first name, A-T-I-T, Atisha. >> Atisha, thank you.
>> Excellent. How about this one?

Also from Atisha, "How do you deal with a constant
push back to new ideas?

This breaks an
individual's confidence in succeeding or taking their
thoughts to a new level."

Can you help with this, Huggy? >> Again, that's a
good question as well. I think the most important
thing is in which stage.

The key thing to understand is great innovative
organizations are also very good at
killing good ideas.

From the perspective
of an organization, if you have $100 and 10 ideas,

the easiest thing is to
allocate 10 bucks to each idea. Here, what we are doing is

we're styling really
good ideas of resources and we are nourishing bad ideas when
they ought to be killed.

But great organizations
kill good ideas too, so they actually put
money in earlier.

The most important thing is, when is an idea killed? I think that's what organizations
aren't good at doing.

In fact, the question reminds
me of an imagery where in

most organizations there's a
committee often called the murder board or the murder

committee that kills
not only the idea, but the person with the idea. We need to think of

less threatening ways
of killing the idea. I don't know whether
you recall this,

but in the scaling of
excellence course, for example, we had a case study
on ride-solutions,

where they use market
mechanisms to kill ideas. When peers kill ideas,

it's a little more acceptable. When a boss kills an idea, because a boss
killing an idea also

translates into some level
of personal invalidation, as your question imply.

>> I could see that, too.
It's a much different thing. As an employee, you
internalize everything

that your manager or your
leader does or says, and so it's just a much different thing if it
comes from, "Well,

the market won't bear it," and then it just gets killed.
Thank you, Huggy. >> Yeah, that's right.

>> We have a question
from John Magnuson. He said, "Do you have
suggestions on how to work

through core value conflicts that are emerging
during the pandemic, such as the telework option
versus office only?"

>> Yeah. That's a
really good question.

>> The pandemic, of course, has had a huge
effect on all of us.

Be affected as handy is, it's actually induced
many of us to think about reinventing the firm.

Bob and I wrote an article for the McKinsey Quarterly
sometime ago.

Maybe we'll make it
available Robin. In this article what Bob
and I suggested was,

one way to think
about the pandemic is actually about leading
in uncertain time.

The imagery we use
in that article was, people are in the room called

fear and if you're in
a room called fear, you're going to be risk averse

and you're likely to
have tunnel vision. You need to be in a room called hope in order to

imagine what is possible
and what can be done.

Getting from the
room called hope to the room called fear
requires passage way.
One of the things that Bob and I were arguing in that article is,

what the pandemic has done, particularly with the advent
of remote work is actually

transfund the
psychological contract between the boss and
the subordinate.

Pre-pandemic if you were a boss, your subordinate work
usually in front

of you or in some close vicinity. You could physically observe the subordinate, monitor
the subordinate.

Subordinates also work with
other people in teams. Now, if you are a subordinate,

you are actually
likely to be alone, working at home for example.

If you're a boss, you
can't see the subordinate. So monitoring is a problem.

If you're alone, can be problem. One of the things Bob
and I suggest is,

the passage away from the room called fear to the
room called hope,

is what we refer to
and what the research refers to as your best self.

Felicia hinted at that too in a wonderfully reflecting
an honest conversation.

What's the best selves? Your best self can easily
be captured in two,

three words, which are verbs, or adverbs, that is actions
that best describe you.

What's the nature of the
psychological contract? The employee comes to work
with his or her best self,

and the boss's job is or
boss's obligation is, how can I give you

opportunities to
express your best self? Because when we bring
our best self to work,
rather than our tired self or fatigued self or angry self,

obviously we're highly motivated. We don't need much monitor. That's the nature of the
psychological contract.

Hopefully that gives
you a sense of that's what's going to make it easier
to actually get into this,

what you referred to as
navigating these choices. The other thing that Bob and
I argue in the article is,

when you're reinventing
the company by going fully remote or

by becoming more distributed
or what have you. You also need to re-own

your employees because they're not working for the same
organization anymore.

So to mine mind, the value conflict
is less a choice
and this more of question of getting your best selves to come, and the best self exercise and

this psychological
contract will rapidly allow you to focus on
the group of values,

but a group of values that
aren't abstract words, but excessively as a behavior.

of a long answer,
